p: Trends in tree growth are often affected by biases introduced by the sampling design (Bowman et al., 2013; Brienen, Gloor, & Zuidema, 2012; Nehrbass‐Ahles et al., 2014) and age trend removal (Peters et al., 2015). A review of past studies on tree growth trends (Bontemps & Esper, 2011; Melvin & Briffa, 2008; Peters et al., 2015) led us to favor regional curve standardization (RCS; Becker, 1989; Briffa et al., 1992) to account for the trees' age trend. For RCS, the cambial age of the tree at coring height is needed. For cores that did not hit the pith, a geometric method was used to estimate the number of missing years to the pith based on ring curvature and the average of the first five measurable ring widths (Duncan, 1989). Cores with more than 10 missing rings were excluded to restrict uncertainty introduced by this estimation.
